thread.title: Colorado snow totals: Christmas storm drops half a foot on some ski areas
thread.title_full: Colorado snow totals: Christmas storm drops half a foot on some ski areas

author: Shelby Valicenti
title: Colorado snow totals: Christmas storm drops half a foot on some ski areas
text:
Colorado snow totals: Christmas storm drops half a foot on some ski areas News | Dec 26, 2024
Summit Daily staff report A skier explores The Beavers while skiing at Arapahoe Basin Ski Area on Friday, Dec. 20, 2024.
Lucas Herbert/Arapahoe Basin Ski Area Snow falling on the evening of Tuesday, Dec. 24 not only brought the magic of a white Christmas, but it snapped a dry spell in Colorado’s mountains .
Summit County’s Breckenridge Ski Resort and Winter Park were the big winners for the week, seeing 7 inches fall. The holiday snowfall brought Breckenridge to 100 inches on the season and Winter Park to 101 inches. Copper Mountain was the first resort to hit 100 inches on the year in late November.
Snow continued through Wednesday and into Thursday, dropping as much as 7 inches on some ski areas in the state. Snow continued to fall through Thursday and is expected to keep accumulating through Monday or Tuesday night. Here’s how much snow resorts totaled from Tuesday through Thursday, according to OpenSnow.com .
3-day snow totals:
Breckenridge Ski Resort, 7 inches
Winter Park Resort, 7 inches
Arapahoe Basin Ski Area, 6 inches
Loveland Ski Area, 6 inches
Aspen Mountain, 5 inches
Beaver Creek, 5 inches
Snowmass, 5 inches
Steamboat Resort, 5 inches
Buttermilk, 4 inches
Copper Mountain Resort, 4 inches
Keystone Resort, 4 inches
Vail Mountain, 3 inches
